text: Hey everyone! Nice to meet you - I recently was tasked out with designing an email template in HubSpot. I'm used to creating editable templates for Campaign Monitor clients. I've been trying to go through the Developer resources in HubSpot and I'm stuck on what next steps and specific template language needs to go in the HTML and a few other things. Would anyone be willing to help me out? I'm at a standstill and feeling a little bit overwhelmed. For example - do we need to build modules within HubSpot and then copy the code over to the HTML editable template code? Or am I completely off?

has anyone here actually implemented this:
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/tutorials/combining-multiple-sets-of-blog-posts-into-a-single-listing>
was wondering if there were any gotchas to watch out for
I have; pagination, topic listing views, and search are the biggest X factors
has the pagination been solved for
It can be, depends on how it’s implemented. To keep things easier, though, usually I’ll opt for a custom index listing page ONLY, then rely on the built-in methods for subsequent pages, topics, etc…
only reason for us building up multiple blogs is because of the need to have multiple templates. I don't think a HubSpot blog instance supports more than 1, right?

The HubL can get complicated and I don’t have any off-hand right now, but if you wanted to do true pagination you would need to build your custom dict by appending the various posts in question, use filters to chunk them according to how many posts should be included per-page, and then use the “current_page_num” variable to get which batch of posts should be displayed on that page.

Each blog can have its own template, and the listing vs individual views can be different templates, but you’re correct that multiple listing templates in one blog is not available.
FYI the only reason we went the blog approach and not a web page approach is because HubSpot doesn't yet have support for tags on for a webpage from what I've read
I mean, it depends what you want to do. You could build your own “tagging” system using HubDB if you wanted by creating a table of pages and a multi-select column.
